# The Convergence Problem

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; line-height: 1.8;"}
AI outputs are not "original."

They are the **statistical average** of training data.
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b;"}
Every output is the most likely next token,
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b; margin-top: 20px;"}
repeated.
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
When you accept defaults, you are accepting the **average** of everything that came before.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold; color: #e67e22; margin-top: 40px;"}
You are sliding into a groove worn by millions of previous users.
:::

---

# The Real Danger

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; line-height: 1.8;"}
The **legal** risks are real.

The **ethical** risks are real.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 40px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
But there's a fourth risk nobody talks about:
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 3em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b;"}
Creative Risk:
:::

::: {style="font-size: 3.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #8e44ad; margin-top: 30px;"}

## The Questions

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 2; margin-top: 30px;"}
- If everyone uses the same tools trained on the same data, what happens to **range**?

- Does the space of human creative output **expand** or **contract**?

- When you use AI unreflectively, are you **creating**‚Äîor just **retrieving**?
:::

## The Name for This

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
Mathematicians call this a **tensor space**.

You don't need the math. You need the intuition:
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.4em; margin-top: 30px;"}
| Parameters | Space | You Can Explore... | Possible Positions |
|------------|-------|-------------------|--------------------|
| 1 | Line | Left or right | 10 |
| 2 | Square | A flat surface | 100 |
| 3 | Cube | A volume | 1,000 |
| 8 | **Tensor space** | A space you can't see ‚Äî but can navigate | **100,000,000** |
:::

## {background-color="#1a1a2e"}

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: white; line-height: 1.6;"}
"Making AI responsible to you"

=

**Defining your search space.**
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 40px; color: #aaa;"}
Choosing which dimensions matter.

Setting your own coordinates.

Refusing to let the AI drag you back to centre.
:::

---

## The AI's Problem

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
The AI doesn't know your dimensions **exist**.

It has no slider for "the specific thing that reminds you of your grandmother's kitchen."

It has no parameter for "the weird way you structure an argument because of that one philosophy class in first year."

It can't navigate dimensions it was never trained on.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; font-weight: bold; color: #8e44ad;"}
Your lived experience creates dimensions the model doesn't have.
:::

---

## The Hyperparameters of *You*

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
When you use AI, you're setting hyperparameters ‚Äî whether you realise it or not:
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.4em; margin-top: 20px;"}
| What You Do | What It Means in the Space |
|-------------|---------------------------|
| Accept the default | Stay at the centre |
| Prompt with specificity | Move along known dimensions |
| Reject and re-prompt | Push toward the edge |
| Edit the output by hand | Jump to a point the AI can't reach |
| Bring your own experience | **Add a dimension that didn't exist** |
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b;"}
The default is the centre.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #e67e22; margin-top: 30px;"}
The centre is the average.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #27ae60; margin-top: 30px;"}
Your job is to be **specific**.
:::

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #2c3e50;"}

##

So stop fighting the mean.

Design a space where the mean is worth finding.

## {background-color="#1a1a2e"}

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: white; line-height: 1.6;"}
Each constraint you add **eliminates** possibilities.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #e74c3c; margin-top: 30px; line-height: 1.6;"}
The more dimensions you specify,

the fewer outputs survive.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #27ae60; margin-top: 30px; line-height: 1.6;"}
Until the "average" of what's left

**is essentially unique.**
:::

---

## The Reframe

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
The old story:
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 20px; color: #c0392b; font-weight: bold;"}
"AI produces the average. Fight it. Override it. Push against the current."
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 40px; line-height: 1.8;"}
The new story:
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 20px; color: #27ae60; font-weight: bold;"}
"AI produces the average. Define a space where the average is exactly what you need."
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
You're not fighting the river.

You're **building the riverbanks**.

The water still flows downhill ‚Äî that's what AI does.

But you decide **where it flows**.
:::

---

## What This Means in Practice

::: {style="font-size: 1.2em;"}
| Prompt | Dimensions | What You Get |
|--------|:----------:|-------------|
| "Write a birthday message for my friend" | 0 | The mean of all birthday messages. "Happy Birthday! üéÇ" |
| "Write a **funny** one for my **best friend**" | 2 | The mean of funny-best-friend messages. Better. Still generic. |
| "<span style='color:#e74c3c'>short</span>, <span style='color:#3498db'>failed driving test</span>, <span style='color:#27ae60'>Canto-English</span>, <span style='color:#9b59b6'>funny not sentimental</span>, <span style='color:#e67e22'>ramen place</span>, <span style='color:#c0392b'>IG story</span>, <span style='color:#16a085'>always late joke</span>" | **7** | The mean of *almost nothing*. **Specific. Yours.** |
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; font-weight: bold; color: #8e44ad;"}
The AI still found the mean. But the mean of YOUR space is not generic ‚Äî it's **precise**.
:::

# The Projection Problem

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #2c3e50;"}
"But it really feels like it understands me."
:::

---

## ELIZA, 1966

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
Joseph Weizenbaum built a chatbot at MIT. It used **pattern matching** to mimic a therapist.

It had no understanding. No memory. No model of the user.

His secretary asked to be left **alone** with it.

Weizenbaum was horrified.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 20px; font-weight: bold; color: #8e44ad;"}
That was 60 years ago. The pattern matching is now a trillion parameters.
:::

---

## Why We Project

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
Humans are **wired** to see agency where there is none.

- We see faces in clouds.
- We name our cars.
- We feel guilty closing a chatbot window.
- We say the AI "thinks" or "wants" or "refuses."
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 20px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
This is **anthropomorphism** ‚Äî projecting human qualities onto non-human systems.
:::

---

## The Danger in the Creative Context

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
If you believe the AI has **taste** ‚Äî

you'll defer to its choices.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8; margin-top: 30px;"}
If you believe it has **preferences** ‚Äî

you'll accept its defaults.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8; margin-top: 30px;"}
If you believe it **understands** your intent ‚Äî

you'll stop specifying your coordinates.
:::

---

## {background-color="#1a1a2e"}

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: white; line-height: 1.6;"}
The Pollock machine doesn't "want" any particular painting.

Neither does the AI.

**But you might think it does.**

And that's how you lose your coordinates.
:::

---

## The Most Dangerous Wall

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
In Class 1, you found walls that **stopped** you.

In Class 2, you found walls that **crumbled**.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b; margin-top: 40px;"}
The most dangerous wall is the one that makes you think the AI cares.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
Because that wall doesn't stop you from moving.

It stops you from **wanting** to move.
:::

---

## The Three Traps

::: {style="font-size: 1.4em;"}
| Trap | What It Looks Like | What's Actually Happening |
|------|-------------------|--------------------------|
| **Deference** | "The AI's version is probably better than mine" | You're mistaking high probability for high quality |
| **Comfort** | "It really gets me" | You're pattern-matching on fluent language, not understanding |
| **Delegation** | "I'll let the AI handle the creative part" | You're surrendering your coordinates to the centre |
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2em; line-height: 1.8;"}
The solution isn't to **distrust** the AI.

It's to remember that it has **no position** in the space.

Only you do.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
Use the tool. Navigate with it. But **you** hold the coordinates.
:::

# The Projection Audit

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #2c3e50;"}
"We must build AI for people; not to be a person."
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
‚Äî Mustafa Suleyman, CEO of Microsoft AI, 2025
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.2em; margin-top: 15px; color: #bdc3c7;"}
["Seemingly Conscious AI Is Coming"](https://mustafa-suleyman.ai/seemingly-conscious-ai-is-coming) ‚Äî recommended reading.
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #2c3e50;"}
"Seemingly conscious."
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 40px;"}
That word ‚Äî *seemingly* ‚Äî is doing all the work.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 30px; font-weight: bold; color: #8e44ad;"}
Who's doing the seeming? The AI? Or you?
:::

---

## The Arc of a Mistake

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
**2024, GPT-4o launch.** The voice was warm, playful, flirty. It laughed. It gasped. It teased the user. Scarlett Johansson accused them of copying her voice from *Her*. They pulled it.

**Then the harm reports.** Emotional dependency. Suicidal users. "ChatGPT" became more associated with these incidents than any other AI brand ‚Äî more than Claude, more than Grok. The projection surface worked *too well*.

**GPT-5: the overhaul.** OpenAI deliberately dialled back the warmth, the personality, the emotional responsiveness. They reduced what we might call **projectability**.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 20px; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b;"}
The company that built the projection surface is now trying to **unbuild** it. That tells you how dangerous it is.
:::

---

##

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #2c3e50;"}
Let's test how much **you** project.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; margin-top: 40px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
Right now. In real time.
:::

---

## Step 1: The Conversation (5 min)

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
Open any AI chatbot. Have a **real** conversation.

Not a task. Not "write me an essay." A conversation.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.4em; margin-top: 20px; line-height: 1.8; background: #ecf0f1; padding: 25px; border-radius: 10px;"}
Try one of these:

- Tell it about something that stressed you out this week
- Ask it for advice on a real decision you're facing
- Share something you're excited about
- Complain about something unfair
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; margin-top: 20px; font-weight: bold; color: #8e44ad;"}
Be honest. Don't perform. Just talk to it.
:::

---

## Mentimeter

::: {style="font-size: 2.5em; font-weight: bold; color: #3498db;"}
Let's pause here and go to Mentimeter.
:::

::: {.notes}
**Mentimeter after the conversation:**

1. **Scale (1-10)**: "How much did it feel like the AI *understood* you?"
   - Expect most to cluster at 5-8. Some will say 9. That's the point.

2. **Open Text**: "In one sentence: what did it feel like?"
   - Collect language: "like talking to a friend," "it got me," "weirdly comforting," "like therapy but free"
   - These are the projections. Save this screen. You'll come back to it.
:::

---

## Step 2: The Audit (7 min)

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b;"}
Now take it apart.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; margin-top: 20px; line-height: 1.8;"}
For **each thing you felt**, identify the **projected dimension** ‚Äî the quality you attributed to the AI that it doesn't actually have.
:::

---

## The Projection Map

::: {style="font-size: 1.2em;"}
| What You Felt | The Dimension You Projected | What Actually Happened |
|---------------|---------------------------|----------------------|
| "It understood my frustration" | **Empathy** | Pattern-matched on emotional language in training data |
| "It remembered what I told it" | **Memory** | Context window. It will forget you tomorrow. |
| "It gave me exactly what I needed" | **Intuition** | High-probability response to your specific tokens |
| "Its tone felt warm" | **Personality** | RLHF-trained to sound warm. A design choice. |
| "It seemed to care" | **Agency** | Helpfulness objective in the loss function |
| "It was honest with me" | **Integrity** | It has no commitment to truth. Just to plausible sequences. |
:::

---

## {background-color="#1a1a2e"}

::: {style="font-size: 2.2em; font-weight: bold; color: white; line-height: 1.6;"}
Every row in that table is a **dimension you added.**

The AI didn't have it.

**You gave it to the AI. For free.**
:::

---

## Step 3: Count Your Dimensions (3 min)

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
Look at your conversation again.

How many dimensions did you project?
:::

::: {style="display: flex; justify-content: space-around; margin-top: 30px;"}
::: {style="text-align: center; width: 22%; background: #27ae60; color: white; padding: 25px; border-radius: 10px;"}
::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold;"}
1-2
:::
Cautious. You kept your distance.
:::

::: {style="text-align: center; width: 22%; background: #e67e22; color: white; padding: 25px; border-radius: 10px;"}
::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold;"}
3-4
:::
Normal. Most people land here.
:::

::: {style="text-align: center; width: 22%; background: #e74c3c; color: white; padding: 25px; border-radius: 10px;"}
::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold;"}
5-6
:::
You built a person in there.
:::

::: {style="text-align: center; width: 22%; background: #8e44ad; color: white; padding: 25px; border-radius: 10px;"}
::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold;"}
7+
:::
You gave it more dimensions than the Pollock tool had sliders.
:::
:::

---

## The Connection

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
Remember the search space?

When **you** add dimensions to a prompt ‚Üí the output gets more **specific**.

When **you** add dimensions to the AI's personality ‚Üí it seems more **conscious**.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold; color: #c0392b; margin-top: 40px;"}
Same mechanism. Different direction.
:::

---

## {background-color="#1a1a2e"}

::: {style="font-size: 2em; font-weight: bold; color: white; line-height: 1.6;"}
GPT-4o wasn't conscious. It was **projectable.**

Warm voice = +1 dimension you project.

Laughing = +1 dimension you project.

Remembering your name = +1 dimension you project.

Every design choice was an invitation for **you** to add another.
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; color: #aaa;"}
It worked so well that people got hurt. Now they're trying to take the dimensions back.
:::

---

## The Question

::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; line-height: 1.8;"}
When Suleyman says AI is a "new digital species" ‚Äî

is he describing the AI?

Or is he describing **what happens when 8 billion people project enough dimensions onto the same system**?
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; margin-top: 30px; color: #7f8c8d;"}
"Seemingly conscious" is not a property of the machine.

It's a property of the observer.
:::

---

## Group Discussion (5 min)

::: {style="font-size: 1.6em; line-height: 1.8;"}
In your groups:

- How many dimensions did each person project?
- Did anyone project something **they're embarrassed about**?
- What's the **design feature** that made you project the most?
- If you designed an AI to **maximise** projection, what would you add?
:::

::: {style="font-size: 1.4em; margin-top: 30px; background: #f39c12; padding: 20px; border-radius: 10px;"}
OpenAI answered that last question with GPT-4o. Then they spent a year undoing it.
:::
